verses.text: When Demetrius learned that Nicanor and his army had been defeated in battle, he sent Bacchides and Alcimus into Judea again, this time together with a division from the army’s right wing.
verses.comment: Demetrius is the Seleucid king mentioned earlier, and this deployment marks another attempt to crush the Jewish resistance. The right wing of the army typically signifies a strong, elite force.

verses.text: They traveled along the road that leads to Gilgal, set up camp near Mesaloth in Arbela, captured the town, and killed many of its inhabitants.
verses.comment: The campaign route is specified, showing the strategic advance. Mesaloth’s capture illustrates the severity of the invading force's violence.

verses.text: In the first month of the one hundred fifty-second year, they laid siege to Jerusalem, encamping nearby.
verses.comment: The year refers to the Seleucid calendar (springtime). The siege of Jerusalem was a recurring event in this period.

verses.text: Afterward, they left for Berea, taking with them twenty thousand infantry and two thousand cavalry.
verses.comment: This verse underscores the overwhelming numbers against the Jewish defenders. Berea’s location is debated, possibly north of Jerusalem.

verses.text: Judas meanwhile had pitched camp at Elasa with about three thousand select men.
verses.comment: Judas’s forces were relatively small, but they were his best fighters. Elasa’s exact location is unknown, though possibly east of Jerusalem.

verses.text: But when they saw the size of the enemy army, fear took hold of them, and many deserted the camp, leaving only about eight hundred men behind.
verses.comment: The drastic reduction in numbers highlights the discouragement and challenge faced by Judas and his loyalists.

verses.text: When Judas realized his troops had deserted and the battle was near, his heart was deeply troubled, since there was no time to gather them back.
verses.comment: The narrative shows Judas grappling with the reality of being left nearly alone, facing imminent danger.

verses.text: Exhausted, he turned to those who remained and said, 'Let us rise and confront our enemies. Perhaps we will be strong enough to fight them.'
verses.comment: Judas’ resolve and encouragement reveal his unwavering faith and courage, even when outnumbered.

verses.text: But his companions tried to persuade him otherwise, saying, 'We do not have the strength. Let us save ourselves now and, together with our brothers, return and fight; we are far too few.'
verses.comment: The hesitancy of Judas’s followers highlights both their realistic fear and the desperate circumstances of the rebels.

verses.text: But Judas replied, 'We should never run away from them. If our time has come, let us die bravely for our people and not leave room for anyone to question our integrity.'
verses.comment: Judas’s answer reflects themes of martyrdom and honor, hallmarks of Maccabean ideology.

verses.text: Then Bacchides’ army came out of their camp, forming up for battle. The cavalry was divided into two squads, and the slingers and archers led the way, joined by all the key fighters.
verses.comment: This order of battle describes standard Hellenistic tactics: archers and slingers ahead, with cavalry and special units divided for maneuverability.

verses.text: Bacchides himself took the right wing. With both divisions on either side, the formation advanced to trumpet blasts, while the men with Judas blew their own trumpets as well.
verses.comment: The phalanx and trumpet signals indicate professional, organized warfare, contrasting the small Jewish force.

verses.text: The clash of the armies was so loud that the ground shook, and the fighting continued from morning until evening.
verses.comment: The intensity of the battle is emphasized, showing both its ferocity and duration.

verses.text: Judas saw that Bacchides and his strongest fighters were stationed on the right, and so all the most courageous men followed him there.
verses.comment: The action focuses on a heroic charge against the main enemy force. The ‘right wing’ maintained a tactical and symbolic significance.

verses.text: Together, they broke through the right wing, chasing them up to Mount Azotus.
verses.comment: Judas’s initial success recalls earlier Maccabean victories, though the outcome will be different here.

verses.text: When the left wing saw their side was defeated, they changed direction and began to pursue Judas and his men.
verses.comment: The battle changes momentum, indicating a shifting advantage in the conflict.

verses.text: The fighting grew fierce, and heavy casualties were suffered on both sides.
verses.comment: Both armies endure significant losses in this pitched engagement.

verses.text: Judas, too, fell in battle, and those who survived fled the field.
verses.comment: This verse marks the death of the book’s hero, a pivotal moment for the community.

verses.text: Jonathan and Simon took the body of their brother Judas and laid him to rest in their ancestral tomb at Modein.
verses.comment: Modein was the Maccabean family's home and burial place, honoring Judas’ legacy.

verses.text: They mourned over him. All Israel joined in loud lament, grieving for many days.
verses.comment: The communal mourning reflects Judas’s significance to the nation.

verses.text: "How the mighty has fallen, the deliverer of Israel!"
verses.comment: Echoes the lament for Saul and Jonathan in Samuel, portraying Judas as a national hero.

verses.text: The events of Judas’s battles, his courageous actions and achievements, were many, though not all are recorded here.
verses.comment: The author acknowledges there are more deeds than this narrative recounts, typical ancient historiography.

verses.text: After Judas’s death, traitors appeared throughout Israel; all sorts of evildoers returned.
verses.comment: This underscores the political and moral crisis following the loss of a strong leader.

verses.text: A severe famine struck that region at the same time, causing most of the people to join the side of the lawless.
verses.comment: Material hardship led to greater instability and shifting loyalties.

verses.text: Bacchides chose the ungodly and made them rulers over the land.
verses.comment: The author makes a theological judgment on these leaders, connecting their rule with infidelity to God.

verses.text: They searched out Judas’s supporters and brought them to Bacchides, who avenged himself on them with cruelty and ridicule.
verses.comment: The fate of Judas’s allies is grim, illustrating the dangers of resisting the occupying power.

verses.text: Distress in Israel was worse than it had ever been since prophets stopped appearing among them.
verses.comment: This highlights the perceived lack of divine guidance during this crisis.

verses.text: Then all those loyal to Judas assembled and spoke to Jonathan:
verses.comment: The narrative now shifts to the rise of Jonathan as successor.

verses.text: "Since your brother Judas died, there has been no one like him to confront our enemies and Bacchides, or to deal with our own people who hate us."
verses.comment: Jonathan is recruited because of his family legacy of leadership and courage.

verses.text: "Today we choose you as our leader and guide, to lead us in battle."
verses.comment: The community turns to Jonathan for protection, showing continuity in leadership.

verses.text: So Jonathan accepted the leadership at that time, stepping into the role of his brother Judas.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s acceptance signals a new era in the revolt, as the author transitions to his exploits.

verses.text: When Bacchides heard about this, he tried to kill Jonathan.
verses.comment: Bacchides continues aggressive measures against the rebel leadership, showing the cycle of violence.

verses.text: But Jonathan, his brother Simon, and their supporters heard of it and withdrew to the wilderness of Tekoa, setting up camp by the pool of Asphar.
verses.comment: Tekoa was southeast of Bethlehem; withdrawal to wilderness is a typical tactic for insurgents.

verses.text: Bacchides found out about this on the Sabbath, and crossed the Jordan River with his entire army.
verses.comment: Crossing the Jordan on the Sabbath again highlights the enemy’s disregard for Jewish religious observance.

verses.text: Jonathan put his brother in charge of the group and asked his Nabatean allies to let them store their large amounts of baggage for safekeeping.
verses.comment: The Nabateans were a powerful tribe southeast of Judea, often allies but sometimes adversaries.

verses.text: But the clan of Jambri from Medeba came out and captured John and all that he had, then escaped with the spoils.
verses.comment: This betrayal by the Jambri illustrates the unpredictable alliances and treacheries of the time.

verses.text: Some time later, Jonathan and Simon heard that the Jambri were celebrating a grand wedding, escorting a bride—the daughter of a prominent Canaanite noble—from Nadabath with a great retinue.
verses.comment: The Jambri’s notable status and the wedding procession serve as a backdrop for the coming retribution.

verses.text: Remembering the death of their brother John, Jonathan and Simon climbed into the mountains and took cover, preparing a surprise attack.
verses.comment: The ambush is in keeping with the Maccabean style of guerrilla warfare.

verses.text: They saw the noisy wedding procession, loaded with baggage. The bridegroom went out to meet the parade with his companions, family, musicians, tambourines—and many armed men.
verses.comment: The dramatic wedding scene heightens tension before the ambush.

verses.text: Jonathan and Simon sprang out from hiding, attacking and killing many; most others ran to the mountain, and the Jews seized all their belongings.
verses.comment: The successful ambush is portrayed as a justified retaliation and results in the spoils of war.

verses.text: The festive wedding turned into grief; the musicians’ joyful songs became funeral laments.
verses.comment: There is poetic irony in this reversal of celebration to mourning after the slaughter.

verses.text: When they had finished avenging their brother's death, Jonathan and Simon returned to the marshes along the Jordan.
verses.comment: The marshes provided cover and a retreat for rebel forces.

verses.text: When Bacchides heard about this, he marched with a large army to the edge of the Jordan on the Sabbath.
verses.comment: Another Sabbath offensive, pressing the Jewish defenders into danger.

verses.text: Jonathan rallied his men, saying, 'Let us rise now and fight for our lives, for today we face a different challenge than before.'
verses.comment: Jonathan takes charge, invoking courage and adaptation in the face of adversity.

verses.text: 'Look—the enemy stands before us and behind; Jordan’s water is on both sides, with marshes and brush all around. There is nowhere to retreat.'
verses.comment: Jonathan’s tactical assessment highlights their dire predicament.

verses.text: 'Call out now to Heaven that God may deliver us from our enemies!'
verses.comment: Jonathan urges the people to pray for divine intervention, consistent with Maccabean piety.

verses.text: The fight began; Jonathan reached out to strike Bacchides, but Bacchides dodged and ran to the rear lines.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s direct attempt to take out the enemy leader is unsuccessful, but shows boldness.

verses.text: Then Jonathan and his men dove into the Jordan and swam across; Baconchides’ troops did not pursue them.
verses.comment: Swimming the Jordan was risky but effective; their narrow escape is highlighted.

verses.text: On that day, about a thousand of Bacchides’s soldiers fell.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s side manages to inflict heavy losses on the enemy.

verses.text: Bacchides returned to Jerusalem and fortified a series of cities throughout Judea: Jericho, Emmaus, Beth-horon, Bethel, Timnath, Pharathon, and Tephon, surrounding them with strong walls, gates, and bars.
verses.comment: These fortifications were to secure Seleucid control and restrict rebel activity.

verses.text: He stationed garrisons in these towns to harass the Jewish population.
verses.comment: Permanent garrisons ensured ongoing oppression of Israel and protected Seleucid interests.

verses.text: He also fortified Beth-zur, Gazara, and the citadel, placing troops and storing provisions in each.
verses.comment: Specific sites were strategic for controlling the region and maintaining supplies.

verses.text: He took the sons of the prominent local families as hostages, locking them up in the citadel in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Taking hostages was a common tactic to ensure loyalty among subject peoples.

verses.text: In the one hundred fifty-third year, during the second month, Alcimus ordered the destruction of the inner wall of the sanctuary—the work built by the prophets.
verses.comment: Alcimus’s mandate attacks the sanctity of the Temple, intensifying religious tensions.

verses.text: But as he started to tear it down, Alcimus was suddenly struck powerless; he lost his speech and became paralyzed, unable to speak or direct his affairs.
verses.comment: Alcimus’s sudden illness was regarded as divine punishment for his sacrilege.

verses.text: He died then in intense suffering.
verses.comment: The death of Alcimus, an unpopular high priest, is portrayed as retribution.

verses.text: When Bacchides learned of Alcimus’s death, he returned to the king, and the land of Judah enjoyed peace for two years.
verses.comment: The withdrawal of Bacchides and interlude of peace allowed for recovery and reorganization.

verses.text: But then the lawless gathered and said, 'Look, Jonathan and his followers are living quietly and without fear. Let us summon Bacchides again so he can capture them all in one night.'
verses.comment: Even in seasons of peace, enemies plot against righteous leadership.

verses.text: They proceeded to ask Bacchides for support.
verses.comment: The leadership’s enemies continually seek support from foreign powers.

verses.text: Bacchides mobilized a large army, secretly sent letters to his allies in Judea, instructing them to seize Jonathan and his men. But they failed, for their plot was discovered.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s spies or supporters were effective in uncovering the conspiracy.

verses.text: Jonathan’s troops tracked down about fifty local leaders behind the treachery and executed them.
verses.comment: The punishment toward betrayers served as a warning and helped suppress further rebellion.

verses.text: Then Jonathan, Simon, and their group withdrew to Bethbasi in the wilderness; they rebuilt the ruins and reinforced its defenses.
verses.comment: Bethbasi’s fortification became a new base of operations for the resistance.

verses.text: When Bacchides heard of this, he assembled his entire force and sent orders to the men of Judea.
verses.comment: Renewed conflict ensues as Bacchides sets out for an extended siege.

verses.text: He camped against Bethbasi, besieged it for many days, and constructed engines of war for the assault.
verses.comment: Typical ancient siege tactics; engines may refer to battering rams and siege towers.

verses.text: Jonathan left Simon in Bethbasi while he went into the surrounding countryside with just a few men.
verses.comment: Splitting his forces was a risk, but allowed for attacks against enemy positions.

verses.text: He attacked and struck down Odomera and his relatives, as well as the people of Phasiron where they camped.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s aggressive tactics continue to erode the enemy’s control.

verses.text: Afterward, a larger battle ensued. Simon and his men launched a sortie from Bethbasi, setting fire to the siege machines.
verses.comment: Destroying siege equipment was essential; Simon’s role becomes prominent here.

verses.text: They fought Bacchides, overwhelmed him, and pressed him hard; his campaign and plans had failed.
verses.comment: This is a turning point, with the Jewish forces gaining the upper hand.

verses.text: Furious with the renegades who advised him to invade, Bacchides put many to death, then resolved to return home.
verses.comment: Internal betrayal and failed advice led Bacchides to take revenge on his own supporters.

verses.text: When Jonathan heard he was leaving, he sent ambassadors to negotiate peace and secure the release of hostages.
verses.comment: Making peace and recovering hostages restores some stability and leadership.

verses.text: Bacchides agreed, and swore to Jonathan that he would not harm him for as long as he lived.
verses.comment: The oath-bound truce provided a rare period of peace for Jonathan.

verses.text: Bacchides returned all the captives he had previously taken from Judea, then withdrew to his own land and did not invade their territory again.
verses.comment: This marks the effective end of Bacchides’s intervention for the time being.

verses.text: Thus warfare ceased in Israel. Jonathan settled at Michmash, began judging the people, and eradicated the wicked from Israel.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s role as leader was clearly established and peace restored—for now.
